Graphs¶

This module contains classes for dealing with graphs. The idea is to provide facilities for general connections between spins in a matrix.

class ising.graph.Copyable[source]¶

Simply represents a thing with a copy method.

copy()[source]¶

Copy the object.

Returns

A copy of this object.

static iscopyable(obj)[source]¶

Returns whether an object has a copy method.

Parameters

obj (object) – The object to determine the copy status.

Returns

True if obj.copy() is valid. False if it is not.

class ising.graph.Vertex(data, index)[source]¶

Represents a vertex. The constructor should not be called. Instead, use the ising.graph.VertexFactory to create vertices.

Parameters

  • data (object) – Any data to store at the vertex.

  • index (int) – The index for this vertex.

getdata()[source]¶

Gets the data at this vertex.

Returns

The data stored at this vertex.

setdata(data)[source]¶

Sets the data at this vertex.

Parameters

data (object) – The new data.

Returns

The new data.

getindex()[source]¶

Gets the index for this vertex.

Returns

The index.

_setindex(index)[source]¶

Sets the index. Should not be called globally.

Parameters

index (int) – The new index.

Returns

The new index.

__eq__(other)[source]¶

Check for equality.

Parameters

other (Vertex or int) – The other thing to check.

Returns

True if the vertices have the same data, or if the

copy()[source]¶

Implementation of Copyable.copy().

Returns

A copy of this instance.

__str__()[source]¶

Returns a string which indicates the index and data.

Returns

String representation.

__hash__()[source]¶

Returns the index. Useful for making dictionaries. It assumes that the vertex object was produced with the VertexFactory class, which ensures unique indices.

Returns

The index.

class ising.graph.Edge(index, start, end[, length = 1])[source]¶

Represents an edge. Assumed to be directed.

Parameters

  • index (int) – The index for the edge.

  • start (Vertex) – The starting vertex.

  • end (Vertex) – The ending vertex.

  • length (object) – The length of the edge.

getstart()[source]¶

Returns the starting node.

Returns

The starting node.

getend()[source]¶

Returns the ending node.

Returns

The ending node.

getlength()[source]¶

Returns the length.

Returns

The length.

setstart(vert)[source]¶

Sets the starting vertex to a new value.

Parameters

vert (Vertex) – The starting vertex.

Returns

The new starting vertex.

setend(vert)[source]¶

Sets the ending vertex to a new value.

Parameters

vert (Vertex) – The ending vertex.

Returns

The new ending vertex.

getindex()[source]¶

Returns the index.

Returns

The index.

_setindex(index)[source]¶

Sets the index to a new value. Should not be called globally.

Parameters

index (int) – The new index.

Returns

The new index.

cantraverse(vert)[source]¶

Returns whether the edge can be traversed from the given vertex.

Parameters

vert (Vertex) – The starting vertex.

Returns

True if the edge can be traversed. False otherwise.

traverse(vert)[source]¶

Traverse this edge from the given vertex.

Parameters

vert (Vertex) – The starting vertex.

Returns

A tuple containing the ending vertex and the length.

__eq__(other)[source]¶

Checks to see if two edges are the same: starting from the same point, going to the same point, and having the same length. If the other is not an edge, it is treated like an index, which is compared to the index of the edge.

Parameters

other (Edge or int.) – The other thing to compare.

Returns

True if the edges are equal, or if this is the referenced edge. False otherwise.

copy()[source]¶

Implementation of Copyable.copy().

Returns

A copy of this object.

__str__()[source]¶

Returns a string which has the index of the edge, the start and end nodes, whether it is directed or not, and the length. An example would look like [0 : (0: "Vertex Data") -> (1) (200)], which has a length of 200, and goes from 0 to 1, with the string "Vertex Data" attached to vertex 0.

Returns

The string representation.

__hash__()[source]¶

Returns the index of the edge. Assumes that the edge was made using the graph.EdgeFactory.

Returns

The index.

class ising.graph.UndirectedEdge(index, start, end[, length = 1])[source]¶

Represents an undirected edge. Implements all the same methods as graph.Edge, but it does not differentiate between the start and end nodes.

class ising.graph.VertexFactory[source]¶

Builds vertices, and ensures that they have unique indices. Extends ising.despats.singleton.Singleton.

makevertex([data])[source]¶

Makes a new vertex.

Parameters

data (object) – Data to attach to the vertex.

Returns

A new vertex.

makevertex_list(nverts[, data])[source]¶

Makes several vertices at a time. If data is iterable, then the factory method will try to attach each vertex with an entry from the data argument. Otherwise, each vertex will get what is passed in the data argument.

Parameters

  • nverts (int) – Number of vertices.

  • data – Data to attach to vertices.

Returns

A list of new vertices.

class ising.graph.EdgeFactory[source]¶

Builds edges, and ensures that they have unique indices. Extends ising.despats.singleton.Singleton.

makeedge(start, end[, length][, directed])[source]¶

Makes a new edge with the given starting node, ending node, and length. Also specifies directed or undirected.

Parameters

  • start (Vertex) – The starting node.

  • end (Vertex) – The ending node.

  • length (object) – The length. Defaults to 1.

  • directed (bool) – True if directed, false if undirected. Defaults to true.

Returns

A new edge.

class ising.graph.Graph(verts, edges)[source]¶

Represents a graph with the given edges and vertices.

getverts()[source]¶

Returns the set of vertices.

Returns

The set of vertices.

getvert(index)[source]¶

Returns a vertex with the given index, or the vertex that equals the given.

Returns

The requested vertex.

getedges()[source]¶

Returns the set of edges.

Returns

The set of edges.

getedge(index[, cutoff])[source]¶

Returns an edge which matches the given data. If the data is a tuple, it is expected to look like (start, end) or (start, end, length). If it is an index, it will look for an edge with that index. The cutoff parameter is for dealing with floating point lengths, which may have round-off errors.

Parameters

  • index (tuple or int) – Critera for the edge to be found.

  • cutoff (float) – The cutoff for floating point equality. Defaults to 1e-6.

Returns

The requested edge.

addverts(vert)[source]¶

Adds a single vertex or several vertices.

Parameters

vert (Vertex or iterable(Vertex)) – The vertex or vertices.

Returns

The set of vertices after adding.

addedges(edge)[source]¶

Adds a single edge or several edges.

Parameters

edge (Edge or iterable(Edge)) – The edge or edges to add.

Returns

The set of edges after adding.

hasvertex(vert)[source]¶

Returns whether a given vertex is in the graph.

Parameters

vert (Vertex or int.) – The vertex to check.

Returns

True if the vertex is in the graph. False if not.

hasedge(edge)[source]¶

Returns whether a given edge is in the graph.

Parameters

edge (Edge or int.) – The edge to check.

Returns

True if the edge is in the graph. False if not.

getneighbors(vert)[source]¶

Get the neighbors of a vertex.

Parameters

vert (Vertex or int.) – The starting vertex.

Returns

A list of tuples. The first element is the end node. The second is the distance. The third is True if the edge is undirected.

ising.graph.dijkstra(graph, start, end)[source]¶

Implementation of Dijkstra’s shortest path algorithm for testing purposes.

Parameters

  • graph (Graph) – The graph to use.

  • start (Vertex) – The starting node.

  • end (Vertex) – The ending node.

Returns

A graph which contains the shortest path.
